repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem

Unlike inlay hints, code lenses are closely related to running commands; a significant number of code lenses are used to execute a command (such as running tests). Therefore, it is necessary to provide a default mapping for them.

## Solution
Add a new default mapping, `grl`, where `l` stands for `lens`.

I am not in favor of the approach in #34813 because when a user needs to execute a code lens, they have usually already selected a specific object. For example, when they see a code lens like `run test` and intend to trigger it, opening a menu with unrelated options leads to a poor user experience. Some servers allow code actions to be triggered from anywhere in the entire buffer (they may use code lenses as an interface to provide any of their custom commands), which would result in the execution of any simple code lens requiring a selection from an already lengthy menu.

comment_data.body: I don't think we should set this default mapping if we don't enable codelens itself by default.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,6 +209,10 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
 
+    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()

comment_data.body: It is possible to set this keymap only when codelens is enabled, but since `gr` is intended for LSP keymaps, I don't think a global setting will be an issue. If a user intends to use this key, it might be better for them to be aware of the conflict during setup rather than discovering it only when codelens is active.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,6 +209,10 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
 
+    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()

comment_data.body: It might also be an education opportunity. If the map is used without Codelens enabled, it could reference the relevant help page.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,6 +209,10 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
 
+    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()

comment_data.body:
> It might also be an education opportunity. If the map is used without Codelens enabled, it could reference the relevant help page.

I don't see what's special about codelens to have this behavior for that feature.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,6 +209,10 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
 
+    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()

comment_data.body: We could also change the `.run` implementation so that it works without enabling the codelens display. This is also what I do in my dotfiles because in many cases the display is sort of redundant for some language servers. E.g. I know that hls will show a `Evaluate` or `Refresh` for doctest comments. It also solves a race where the refresh hasn't happened yet and `.run` would operate on the stale state.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,6 +209,10 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
 
+    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()

comment_data.body:
My assumption when implementing the `run()` function in the codelens is that the user triggers this operation because they *saw* a certain code lens, so code lenses that haven't been refreshed are ignored.

If we intend to implement triggering code lens when it's not visible, we're essentially implementing a `vim.lsp.buf.codelens`, which functions very similarly to `vim.lsp.buf.code_action`.

However, I'm not opposed to such an approach. This pattern might be worth promotingâ€”a manually triggered method combined with an automatic updating one. In https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/37644#issuecomment-3843219470, we discussed how to handle document links. It seems this could be done similarly as well.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -209,6 +209,10 @@ do
       vim.lsp.buf.code_action()
     end, { desc = 'vim.lsp.buf.code_action()' })
 
+    vim.keymap.set('n', 'grl', function()

comment_regular_data.body:
> I am not in favor of the approach in #34813 because when a user needs to execute a code lens, they have usually already selected a specific object. For example, when they see a code lens like `run test` and intend to trigger it, opening a menu with unrelated options leads to a poor user experience.

Fair point, but how does "selection" work in that case for a codelens? I assume a codelens is displayed when the cursor is in a particular region. Then instead of clicking on the codelens, the user hits `grl` ?

But multiple codelenses may apply to the same region, so in that case still a menu is needed.

btw, what about `grx` ? "x" seems to be the convention for running/eXecuting stuff.

> Fair point, but how does "selection" work in that case for a codelens? I assume a codelens is displayed when the cursor is in a particular region. Then instead of clicking on the codelens, the user hits `grl` ?

`vim.lsp.codelens.run` triggers the code lens for the current line. If there is only one code lens, it executes directly; if there are multiple, it opens `vim.ui.select`. This is quite different from code actions, which still open a menu even when there is only one option.


> btw, what about `grx` ? "x" seems to be the convention for running/eXecuting stuff.


That sounds good too, but another question is whether to include inlay hints. Inlay hints can also execute commands, but the visibility of this feature is quite low. but we might want to avoid displaying it in the same menu, thus increasing the number of items.

Is there a chance of grx being used for documentLink?

> That sounds good too, but another question is whether to include inlay hints. Inlay hints can also execute commands, but the visibility of this feature is quite low. but we might want to avoid displaying it in the same menu, thus increasing the number of items.

This feels like something that would combine more naturally with Codelenses than Code Actions, since both Lenses and Inlay Hints use Virtual Text to explicitly represent they are available.

> Is there a chance of grx being used for documentLink?

`gx` is perfect for document link.

labels.description: Need comments/opinions from people familiar with this topic.
labels.name: needs:discussion

title: feat(defaults): map 'grl' to `vim.lsp.codelens.run()`
